column2: For two days Tarzan of the Apes had been hunting leisurely to the north, and swinging in a wide circle, he had returned to within a short distance of the clearing where he had left Bertha Kircher and the young lieutenant.
column3: For two days Tarzan of the Apes had been hunting leisurely to the north, and swinging in a wide circle, he had returned to within a short distance of the clearing where he had left Bertha Kircher and the young lieutenant.

column2: He had spent the night in a large tree that overhung the river only a short distance from the clearing, and now in the early morning hours he was crouching at the water's edge waiting for an opportunity to capture Pisah, the fish, thinking that he would take it back with him to the hut where the girl could cook it for herself and her companion.
column3: He had spent the night in a large tree that overhung the river only a short distance from the clearing, and now in the early morning hours he was crouching at the water's edge waiting for an opportunity to capture Pisah, the fish, thinking that he would take it back with him to the hut where the girl could cook it for herself and her companion.

column2: Motionless as a bronze statue was the wily ape-man, for well he knew how wary is Pisah, the fish.
column3: Motionless as a bronze statue was the wily ape man, for well he knew how wary is Pisah, the fish.

column2: The slightest movement would frighten him away and only by infinite patience might he be captured at all.

column2: His knowledge of the ways of the denizens of the water told him where to wait for Pisah.
column3: His knowledge of the ways of the denizens of the water told him where to wait for Pisah.

column3: It might be a minute or it might be an hour before the fish would swim into the little pool above which he crouched, but sooner or later one would come.

column2: The moment that he turned he saw that the author of the disturbance was Zu-tag.
column3: The moment that he turned he saw that the author of the disturbance was Zu tag.

column2: What does Zu-tag want? asked the ape-man.
column3: What does Zu tag want? asked the ape man.

column2: Zu-tag comes to the water to drink, replied the ape.

column2: Where is the tribe? asked Tarzan.
column3: Where is the tribe? asked Tarzan.

column2: They are hunting for pisangs and scimatines farther back in the forest, replied Zu-tag.

column2: The hut and boma were as he had left them, but there was no sign of either the man or the woman.

column2: Crossing the clearing, he entered the boma and then the hut.
column3: Crossing the clearing, he entered the boma and then the hut.

column2: Both were empty, and his trained nostrils told him that they had been gone for at least two days.

column2: As he was about to leave the hut he saw a paper pinned upon the wall with a sliver of wood and taking it down, he read:
column3: As he was about to leave the hut he saw a paper pinned upon the wall with a sliver of wood and taking it down, he read:

column2: After what you told me about Miss Kircher, and knowing that you dislike her, I feel that it is not fair to her and to you that we should impose longer upon you.
column3: After what you told me about Miss Kircher, and knowing that you dislike her, I feel that it is not fair to her and to you that we should impose longer upon you.

column2: I know that our presence is keeping you from continuing your journey to the west coast, and so I have decided that it is better for us to try and reach the white settlements immediately without imposing further upon you.
column3: I know that our presence is keeping you from continuing your journey to the west coast, and so I have decided that it is better for us to try and reach the white settlements immediately without imposing further upon you.

column2: We both thank you for your kindness and protection.
column3: We both thank you for your kindness and protection.

column2: If there was any way that I might repay the obligation I feel, I should be only too glad to do so.
column3: If there was any way that I might repay the obligation I feel, I should be only too glad to do so.

column2: It was signed by Lieutenant Harold Percy Smith-Oldwick.
column3: It was signed by Lieutenant Harold Percy Smith Oldwick.

column2: Tarzan shrugged his shoulders, crumpled the note in his hand and tossed it aside.
column3: Tarzan shrugged his shoulders, crumpled the note in his hand and tossed it aside.

column2: He felt a certain sense of relief from responsibility and was glad that they had taken the matter out of his hands.
column3: He felt a certain sense of relief from responsibility and was glad that they had taken the matter out of his hands.

column2: They were gone and would forget, but somehow he could not forget.
column3: They were gone and would forget, but somehow he could not forget.

column2: He walked out across the boma and into the clearing.
column3: He walked out across the boma and into the clearing.

column2: He felt uneasy and restless.
column3: He felt uneasy and restless.

column2: Once he started toward the north in response to a sudden determination to continue his way to the west coast.
column3: Once he started toward the north in response to a sudden determination to continue his way to the west coast.

column2: He would follow the winding river toward the north a few miles where its course turned to the west and then on toward its source across a wooded plateau and up into the foothills and the mountains.
column3: He would follow the winding river toward the north a few miles where its course turned to the west and then on toward its source across a wooded plateau and up into the foothills and the mountains.

column2: Upon the other side of the range he would search for a stream running downward toward the west coast, and thus following the rivers he would be sure of game and water in plenty.
column3: Upon the other side of the range he would search for a stream running downward toward the west coast, and thus following the rivers he would be sure of game and water in plenty.

column2: But he did not go far.
column3: But he did not go far.

column2: A dozen steps, perhaps, and he came to a sudden stop.
column3: A dozen steps, perhaps, and he came to a sudden stop.

column2: He is an Englishman, he muttered, "and the other is a woman.
column3: He is an Englishman, he muttered, "and the other is a woman.

column2: They can never reach the settlements without my help. I could not kill her with my own hands when I tried, and if I let them go on alone, I will have killed her just as surely as though I had run my knife into her heart.
column3: They can never reach the settlements without my help. I could not kill her with my own hands when I tried, and if I let them go on alone, I will have killed her just as surely as though I had run my knife into her heart.

column2: Tarzan of the Apes is a fool and a weak, old woman, and he turned back toward the south.
column3: Tarzan of the Apes is a fool and a weak, old woman, and he turned back toward the south.

column2: Manu, the monkey, had seen the two Tarmangani pass two days before. Chattering and scolding, he told Tarzan all about it.
column3: Manu, the monkey, had seen the two Tarmangani pass two days before. Chattering and scolding, he told Tarzan all about it.

column2: They had gone in the direction of the village of the Gomangani, that much had Manu seen with his own eyes, so the ape-man swung on through the jungle in a southerly direction and though with no concentrated effort to follow the spoor of those he trailed, he passed numerous evidences that they had gone this way--faint suggestions of their scent spoor clung lightly to leaf or branch or bole that one or the other had touched, or in the earth of the trail their feet had trod, and where the way wound through the gloomy depth of dank forest, the impress of their shoes still showed occasionally in the damp mass of decaying vegetation that floored the way.
column3: They had gone in the direction of the village of the Gomangani, that much had Manu seen with his own eyes, so the ape man swung on through the jungle in a southerly direction and though with no concentrated effort to follow the spoor of those he trailed, he passed numerous evidences that they had gone this way-faint suggestions of their scent spoor clung lightly to leaf or branch or bole that one or the other had touched, or in the earth of the trail their feet had trod, and where the way wound through the gloomy depth of dank forest, the impress of their shoes still showed occasionally in the damp mass of decaying vegetation that floored the way.

column2: An inexplicable urge spurred Tarzan to increasing, speed.
column3: An inexplicable urge spurred Tarzan to increasing, speed.

column2: The same still, small voice that chided him for having neglected them seemed constantly whispering that they were in dire need of him now.
column3: The same still, small voice that chided him for having neglected them seemed constantly whispering that they were in dire need of him now.

column2: Tarzan's conscience was troubling him, which accounted for the fact that he compared himself to a weak, old woman, for the ape-man, reared in savagery and inured to hardships and cruelty, disliked to admit any of the gentler traits that in reality were his birthright.

column2: The trail made a detour to the east of the village of the Wamabos, and then returned to the wide elephant path nearer to the river, where it continued in a southerly direction for several miles.
column3: The trail made a detour to the east of the village of the Wamabos, and then returned to the wide elephant path nearer to the river, where it continued in a southerly direction for several miles.

column2: At last there came to the ears of the ape-man a peculiar whirring, throbbing sound.
column3: At last there came to the ears of the ape man a peculiar whirring, throbbing sound.

column2: For an instant he paused, listening intently, "An aeroplane!" he muttered, and hastened forward at greatly increased speed.
column3: For an instant he paused, listening intently, "An aeroplane!" he muttered, and hastened forward at greatly increased speed.

column2: When Tarzan of the Apes finally reached the edge of the meadowland where Smith-Oldwick's plane had landed, he took in the entire scene in one quick glance and grasped the situation, although he could scarce give credence to the things he saw.
column3: When Tarzan of the Apes finally reached the edge of the meadowland where Smith Oldwick's plane had landed, he took in the entire scene in one quick glance and grasped the situation, although he could scarce give credence to the things he saw.

column2: Bound and helpless, the English officer lay upon the ground at one side of the meadow, while around him stood a number of the black deserters from the German command.
column3: Bound and helpless, the English officer lay upon the ground at one side of the meadow, while around him stood a number of the black deserters from the German command.

column2: Tarzan had seen these men before and knew who they were.
column3: Tarzan had seen these men before and knew who they were.

column2: Coming toward him down the meadow was an aeroplane piloted by the black Usanga and in the seat behind the pilot was the white girl, Bertha Kircher.
column3: Coming toward him down the meadow was an aeroplane piloted by the black Usanga and in the seat behind the pilot was the white girl, Bertha Kircher.

column2: How it befell that the ignorant savage could operate the plane, Tarzan could not guess nor had he time in which to speculate upon the subject.
column3: How it befell that the ignorant savage could operate the plane, Tarzan could not guess nor had he time in which to speculate upon the subject.

column2: His knowledge of Usanga, together with the position of the white man, told him that the black sergeant was attempting to carry off the white girl.
column3: His knowledge of Usanga, together with the position of the white man, told him that the black sergeant was attempting to carry off the white girl.

column2: Why he should be doing this when he had her in his power and had also captured and secured the only creature in the jungle who might wish to defend her in so far as the black could know, Tarzan could not guess, for he knew nothing of Usanga's twenty-four dream wives nor of the black's fear of the horrid temper of Naratu, his present mate.
column3: Why he should be doing this when he had her in his power and had also captured and secured the only creature in the jungle who might wish to defend her in so far as the black could know, Tarzan could not guess, for he knew nothing of Usanga's twenty four dream wives nor of the black's fear of the horrid temper of Naratu, his present mate.

column2: He did not know, then, that Usanga had determined to fly away with the white girl never to return, and to put so great a distance between himself and Naratu that the latter never could find him again; but it was this very thing that was in the black's mind although not even his own warriors guessed it.
column3: He did not know, then, that Usanga had determined to fly away with the white girl never to return, and to put so great a distance between himself and Naratu that the latter never could find him again; but it was this very thing that was in the black's mind although not even his own warriors guessed it.

column2: He had told them that he would take the captive to a sultan of the north and there obtain a great price for her and that when he returned they should have some of the spoils.
column3: He had told them that he would take the captive to a sultan of the north and there obtain a great price for her and that when he returned they should have some of the spoils.

column2: These things Tarzan did not know.
column3: These things Tarzan did not know.

column2: All he knew was what he saw--a Negro attempting to fly away with a white girl.
column3: All he knew was what he saw-a Negro attempting to fly away with a white girl.

column2: Already the machine was slowly leaving the ground.
column3: Already the machine was slowly leaving the ground.

column2: In a moment more it would rise swiftly out of reach.
column3: In a moment more it would rise swiftly out of reach.

column2: At first Tarzan thought of fitting an arrow to his bow and slaying Usanga, but as quickly he abandoned the idea because he knew that the moment the pilot was slain the machine, running wild, would dash the girl to death among the trees.
column3: At first Tarzan thought of fitting an arrow to his bow and slaying Usanga, but as quickly he abandoned the idea because he knew that the moment the pilot was slain the machine, running wild, would dash the girl to death among the trees.

column2: There was but one way in which he might hope to succor her--a way which if it failed must send him to instant death and yet he did not hesitate in an attempt to put it into execution.
column3: There was but one way in which he might hope to succor her-a way which if it failed must send him to instant death and yet he did not hesitate in an attempt to put it into execution.

column2: Usanga did not see him, being too intent upon the unaccustomed duties of a pilot, but the blacks across the meadow saw him and they ran forward with loud and savage cries and menacing rifles to intercept him.
column3: Usanga did not see him, being too intent upon the unaccustomed duties of a pilot, but the blacks across the meadow saw him and they ran forward with loud and savage cries and menacing rifles to intercept him.

column2: They saw a giant white man leap from the branches of a tree to the turf and race rapidly toward the plane.
column3: They saw a giant white man leap from the branches of a tree to the turf and race rapidly toward the plane.

column2: They saw him take a long grass rope from about his shoulders as he ran.
column3: They saw him take a long grass rope from about his shoulders as he ran.

column2: They saw the noose swinging in an undulating circle above his head.
column3: They saw the noose swinging in an undulating circle above his head.

column2: They saw the white girl in the machine glance down and discover him.
column3: They saw the white girl in the machine glance down and discover him.

column2: Twenty feet above the running ape-man soared the huge plane.
column3: Twenty feet above the running ape man soared the huge plane.

column2: The open noose shot up to meet it, and the girl, half guessing the ape-man's intentions, reached out and caught the noose and, bracing herself, clung tightly to it with both hands.
column3: The open noose shot up to meet it, and the girl, half guessing the ape man's intentions, reached out and caught the noose and, bracing herself, clung tightly to it with both hands.

column2: Simultaneously Tarzan was dragged from his feet and the plane lurched sideways in response to the new strain.
column3: Simultaneously Tarzan was dragged from his feet and the plane lurched sideways in response to the new strain.

column2: Usanga clutched wildly at the control and the machine shot upward at a steep angle.
column3: Usanga clutched wildly at the control and the machine shot upward at a steep angle.

column2: Dangling at the end of the rope the ape-man swung pendulum-like in space.
column3: Dangling at the end of the rope the ape man swung pendulum like in space.

column2: The Englishman, lying bound upon the ground, had been a witness of all these happenings. His heart stood still as he saw Tarzan's body hurtling through the air toward the tree tops among which it seemed he must inevitably crash; but the plane was rising rapidly, so that the beast-man cleared the top-most branches.
column3: The Englishman, lying bound upon the ground, had been a witness of all these happenings. column2: Then slowly, hand over hand, he climbed toward the fuselage.

column2: The girl, clinging desperately to the noose, strained every muscle to hold the great weight dangling at the lower end of the rope.
column3: The girl, clinging desperately to the noose, strained every muscle to hold the great weight dangling at the lower end of the rope.

column2: Usanga, all unconscious of what was going on behind him, drove the plane higher and higher into the air.
column3: Usanga, all unconscious of what was going on behind him, drove the plane higher and higher into the air.

column2: Below him the tree tops and the river passed rapidly to the rear and only a slender grass rope and the muscles of a frail girl stood between him and the death yawning there thousands of feet below.
column3: Below him the tree tops and the river passed rapidly to the rear and only a slender grass rope and the muscles of a frail girl stood between him and the death yawning there thousands of feet below.

column3: It seemed to her that those lifeless fingers must relax at any instant and then, when she had about given up hope, she saw a strong brown hand reach up and grasp the side of the fuselage.

column2: Instantly the weight upon the rope was removed and a moment later Tarzan of the Apes raised his body above the side and threw a leg over the edge. He glanced forward at Usanga and then, placing his mouth close to the girl's ear he cried: "Have you ever piloted a plane?" The girl nodded a quick affirmative.

column2: Have you the courage to climb up there beside the black and seize the control while I take care of him?

column2: Tarzan realized that only through a miracle of chance could they reach Usanga and effect the change in pilots and yet he knew that that chance must be taken, for in the brief moments since he had first seen the plane, he had realized that the black was almost without experience as a pilot and that death surely awaited them in any event should the black sergeant remain at the control.

column2: Usanga clawed the air and shrieked but he was helpless as a babe.

column2: You saved yourself, he insisted, "for had you been unable to pilot the plane, I could not have helped you, and now," he said, "you two have the means of returning to the settlements.
column3: You saved yourself, he insisted, "for had you been unable to pilot the plane, I could not have helped you, and now," he said, "you two have the means of returning to the settlements.

column2: The day is still young.
column3: The day is still young.

column2: You can easily cover the distance in a few hours if you have sufficient petrol." He looked inquiringly toward the aviator.
column3: You can easily cover the distance in a few hours if you have sufficient petrol." He looked inquiringly toward the aviator.

column2: Smith-Oldwick nodded his head affirmatively.
column3: Smith Oldwick nodded his head affirmatively.

column2: I have plenty, he replied.
column3: I have plenty, he replied.

column2: Then go at once, said the ape-man.
column3: Then go at once, said the ape man.

column2: Neither of you belong in the jungle. A slight smile touched his lips as he spoke.
column3: Neither of you belong in the jungle. A slight smile touched his lips as he spoke.

column2: The girl and the Englishman smiled too.
column3: The girl and the Englishman smiled too.

column2: This jungle is no place for us at least, said Smith-Oldwick, "and it is no place for any other white man.
column3: This jungle is no place for us at least, said Smith Oldwick, "and it is no place for any other white man.

column2: Why don't you come back to civilization with us?"
column3: Why don't you come back to civilization with us?"

column2: Tarzan shook his head.
column3: Tarzan shook his head.

column2: I prefer the jungle, he said.
column3: I prefer the jungle, he said.

column2: The aviator dug his toe into the ground and still looking down, blurted something which he evidently hated to say.
column3: The aviator dug his toe into the ground and still looking down, blurted something which he evidently hated to say.

column2: If it is a matter of living, old top, he said, "er--money, er--you know--"
column3: If it is a matter of living, old top, he said, "er-money, er-you know-"

column2: Tarzan laughed.
column3: Tarzan laughed.

column2: No, he said.
column3: No, he said.

column2: I know what you are trying to say. It is not that.	I know what you are trying to say. It is not that.
column3: true

column2: I was born in the jungle.
column3: I was born in the jungle.

column2: I have lived all my life in the jungle, and I shall die in the jungle.
column3: I have lived all my life in the jungle, and I shall die in the jungle.

column2: I do not wish to live or die elsewhere."
column3: I do not wish to live or die elsewhere."

column2: The others shook their heads.
column3: The others shook their heads.

column2: They could not understand him.
column3: They could not understand him.

column2: Go, said the ape-man.
column3: Go, said the ape man.

column2: The quicker you go, the quicker you will reach safety.
column3: The quicker you go, the quicker you will reach safety.

column2: They walked to the plane together.
column3: They walked to the plane together.

column2: Smith-Oldwick pressed the ape-man's hand and clambered into the pilot's seat.
column3: Smith Oldwick pressed the ape man's hand and clambered into the pilot's seat.

column2: Good-bye, said the girl as she extended her hand to Tarzan.
column3: Good bye, said the girl as she extended her hand to Tarzan.

column2: Before I go won't you tell me you don't hate me any more? Tarzan's face clouded. Without a word he picked her up and lifted her to her place behind the Englishman.
column3: Before I go won't you tell me you don't hate me any more? Tarzan's face clouded. Without a word he picked her up and lifted her to her place behind the Englishman.

column2: An expression of pain crossed Bertha Kircher's face.
column3: An expression of pain crossed Bertha Kircher's face.

column2: The motor started and a moment later the two were being borne rapidly toward the east.
column3: The motor started and a moment later the two were being borne rapidly toward the east.

column2: In the center of the meadow stood the ape-man watching them.
column3: In the center of the meadow stood the ape man watching them.

column2: It is too bad that she is a German and a spy, he said, "for she is very hard to hate."
